message: Hello teacher

Okay so I am soon going to enter college, and I am going to be learning computer science... I am very excited to begin this journey, and I wish to start learning C programming. Can you please help me out with it? Learning C in a very elegant way, that no one has ever done before?
I have no clue about programming, can you please walk me through in a way that's very intuitive and like an amazing enjoyable journey of exploration instead of a boring lecture.
Wow, is that so?
A programming language...? Like C?
Oh! I remember learning something about gates, but I didn't exactly understand it and thus don't remember what exactly do they mean. I'm sorry.
Oh yes! I remember learning about them in physics class, they are made of semiconductors which allow the current to flow in only a particular direction.
Yes...
I didn't quite get you. And is simply used to join the two clauses here, to combine the two statements into one.
No, it means both the statements are true.
It's partially true.
No
That means you would either like to have tea or coffee. Right?
What? That doesn't make sense to me...
Yes, that's right.
Ohh, so only one of them needs to be true...
Oh, I get it now. But what if we want a condition that only one of them can be true, only then the conjunction of the statements will evaluate to true?
Oh that's interesting! So what are the fundamental logical conditions? AND and OR, that's all?
It simply negates the meaning of the original statement?
Oh yeah! This is binary, the language of computers!
I think it will be low because logically, AND only gives true or high when both of its inputs are high. Here one of them is low, so it gives a low signal as the output.
Yeah that's right, it wouldn't be possible at all probably keeping in track what every combination means, and how to manually convey it to the hardware.
Ohhhh, that's so interesting!
It does! I am so excited to learn it!
I am not sure.
Input devices, Output devices, getting some hints...
Uhm... Write?
Oh I see.
Computer?
Wow, that's an interesting fact, now did the B programming language originate from the A programming language?
LOL, that was unexpected.
Yes, I agree, and probably the syntax or rules are even stricter here because a computer needs a very specific structure of instructions to understand us.
Oh okay, yes, next?
Oh, um, I can't think of anything... Okay let's just print "Hiii".
Oh, ok.
Oh I see...
Oh, that looks kinda weird.
Oh that makes sense, it also kinda gives a programmatic feel to what we are writing.
Oh, it does not run, and shows some sort of errors.
Oh, how do we tell it then?
Yes, what's that?
Oh I see, so how exactly do we write this main function?
Nothing goes inside these parentheses?
Oh, like this? main(){}
Oh, so I think I should write main(){printf("Hiii!");}? This looks so messy.
Oh, looks much better, now let me try to run this.
Oh, it's still not running, shows errors again.
Yes, whole numbers? Also the negative ones, non fractional?
Umm, I am confused, like I understood most of the part but I don't get the returning part.
The number 8
It's a number.
integer add()?
Oh int add()
Oh it doesn't have a return type!
I don't know, who will it return the value to?
Thank you haha, it was a question that genuinely came to my mind. So what do we do now that we don't want it to return a value.
A vast region of emptiness?
Oh
Oh that's great!
Oh is that so, but why? And where does it go?
Oh
Oh. So what is this standard value?
Oh I see
I don't know how to return values though
Okay, do I need to enclose the 0 in quotation marks?
Why?
Oh it says void, I need to change it to int
Do we need to add a semi-colon at the end too, after the curly bracket closes?
Okay, so now I guess this should run...
Oh, it still doesn't work, it says something like printf is undefined... Idk what this means we have tried and fixed everything, why is this still not working?
Oh, what does that mean?
What? Is that so?

Wow, that's interesting, but this looks really complicated... I don't think programming is for me, I don't think I will be able to describe functions so precisely from scratch, dealing with 1s and 0s. I'm sorry you teach really well, but it's too difficult for me I guess.
Oh, so there is one for printf function?
That sounds so much fun! So where exactly is this printf function defined?
Oh, how do we access it and connect it to our printf function and make our program work?
Outside the main function?
It works! I can see Hiii written on the output screen! Wow this is amazing!!!

No, I really loved your style of teaching, it made me explore things myself and was so much more enjoyable rather than a tutorial that would paste the standard Hello World program in front of me and simply ask me to run it first.
It was so much fun, you are such a great teacher!

Yes you are right. Oh and I would have guessed the function's name to be read, but now that there's the o/p function named printf, let me think... So a printer is used for o/p, and it's analogous device used for i/p is a scanner, so is the input function named scanf by any chance?
Wow, that was unexpected!
Thank you and see you soon! Have a nice day!
